Dr. Miranda Grey.Action: Smiles thank you to husband Douglas.
Shows detached, autopilot manner during swimming; emotionally flat.
Performs regular domestic routines (buying coffee for two, family breakfast).
Wakes up just before alarm, indicating punctuality and self-discipline.
Swims laps with steady breathing and focus, showing physical discipline and mental control.
Pays for coffees and newspaper efficiently, demonstrating everyday practical competence.
Studies a case file during breakfast, indicating dedication and professional engagement.
Appears detached and on autopilot during swimming, possibly showing emotional detachment or lack of engagement.
Responds calmly and professionally to Chloe's shocking admission without judgement.
Encourages Chloe by acknowledging her progress in admitting the truth.
Maintains even temperament and redirects conversation gently despite provocative behavior.
Shows little personal emotional reaction, indicating professional detachment.
Maintains professional composure and even keel while a patient reveals disturbing information, responding calmly and encouragingly.
Redirects patient's inappropriate and provocative comments back to the subject of the therapy session to maintain focus.
Nods for orderlies to escort Chloe despite Chloe's dramatic resistance, showing professional composure and respect.
Reassures Chloe by saying 'I didn't say you were crazy' after Chloe suggests it herself, showing tolerance and empathy.
Checks the clock and encourages Chloe to get some sleep, demonstrating care and concern for patient wellbeing.
Shares a friendly, respectful, and easy rapport with Dr. Pete Graham, her best friend at work.
Turns down a job offer, deciding to stay where she is.
Demonstrates social awareness by negotiating a dinner appointment with Parsons despite his busy schedule.
Is about to exit the room when Parsons stops her, indicating professional respect and understanding of office dynamics.
Politely converses with Sheriff Ryan, communicates concern about her husband in a lighthearted way.
Immediately tries to help and protect the teenage girl who appears vulnerable, telling someone on the phone to stay on the line and not go anywhere.
Responds calmly to the emergency blocking her way and takes the advice of the sheriff without argument.
Recognizes the need to alert someone by calling but continues driving despite distractions.
Swerves abruptly to avoid hitting a teenage girl suddenly standing in front of her car, manages to brake and regain control to stop the vehicle.
Distracted by a dropped phone while driving, contributing to the near-accident with the girl.
Approaches injured girl cautiously, reassures her, wraps her coat around her, and intends to get her to hospital.
Tells the girl 'Don't be scared. It's going to be fine.'
Tries to push the girl's hands off when they become overly aggressive.
Attempts to help the injured girl by speaking calmly, wrapping her in a coat, and reassuring her.
Keeps trying to communicate with the unresponsive girl, trying to get her to provide her name.
Shows panic and is physically overwhelmed when the girl unexpectedly and violently pries her mouth open.
Frantically pounds on the locked door and calls for help, showing fear and desperation.
Realizes she is locked inside a cell and tries to find a way out.
Wakes up disoriented but quickly assesses surroundings, identifies being in a cell, tries the door handle and pounds on the door for help.
Argues firmly for her own preferences and expresses frustration clearly when medicated against her will.
Wears patient uniform and is vulnerable but maintains clear communication and seeks explanation.
Expresses frustration and vulnerability by questioning Pete and acknowledging her distress.
Takes medication despite obvious upset, showing cooperation and trust toward Pete in a difficult situation.

Stares at medication trying to put situation into perspective.
Takes medication despite obvious distress and mistrust.
Challenging Pete directly, questioning situation and treatment.
Refuses to be relaxed or compliant just to make situation easier.
Reciting professional background aloud under duress when asked basic questions.
Struggles to respond when Pete questions how long she has been hospitalized, showing vulnerability and confusion.
Expresses immediate concern for Doug, indicating care for others despite her own condition.
Remains silent and speechless as reality of her condition sinks in, not defensive or hostile.
Wants to respond confidently but is unable to answer how long she has been at the facility, revealing a gap in her self-awareness and memory.
Despite her confusion and recent trauma, she tries to assert her identity as a doctor, showing some awareness of her professional role.
Responds with disbelief to the medical explanations about her condition, indicating difficulty accepting or processing the information due to her current impaired state.
Attempts to make a plan to contact Doug (presumably someone close to her) despite being in a compromised mental state, showing a slight proactive impulse.
Shares detailed personal recollections honestly despite emotional difficulty.
Acknowledges logical, unemotional self-presentation as a possible cover for hidden emotions.
Struggles silently with internal emotional turmoil without immediately seeking support.
Expresses concern about the beaten girl, insisting she saw her bleeding and trying to recall details to help.
Appears foggy and shaken, but persists in trying to piece together the truth despite confusion.
Is hesitant and unsure about recalling phone calls or details, showing vulnerability and sincerity.
Tries to recall details of the night and appears confused and foggy on key information.
Attempts to piece together her memories under pressure and respond to interrogation calmly.
Denies trouble in her marriage despite evidence, tries to make a phone call to Doug, reacts with disbelief and sorrow upon learning he is dead, breaks down in hysteria.

Clumsily tries to maintain composure and apologizes for her behavior, expressing regret.
Attempts to leave the loft, setting boundaries with Pete, indicating discomfort with his behavior.
Miranda grabs a drink and responds methodically when the principal comments, showing composure and social awareness in a formal setting.
Miranda tries to fix her smeared lipstick and hair before leaving, showing concern for her appearance despite being flustered.
Miranda admits being married and calls the current situation a mistake, showing self-awareness and honesty.

Touches face tenderly to Pete, showing care despite conflict.

Acknowledges spending time together daily but rejects time together alone, showing restraint.

Engages in personal emotional conflict, seeming torn and hesitant about her situation.
Feels like a school kid hiding, implying insecurity or lack of confidence in current circumstances.
Bangs on the door repeatedly calling for assistance, showing concern and an attempt to get help.

Tries to rationalize the terrifying situation by reminding herself it is a dream and invokes logical reasoning despite fear.

Fails to effectively communicate or convince Irene and staff of her calmness and reason, resulting in forced sedation.

Slow to respond to greeting due to being heavily drugged, looks glazed and out of it.

Slides back the newspaper clipping silently, unsure how to respond to Shelley's probing.

Observes other patients with silent empathy, noting their scars and tattoos as 'maps of troubled souls.'

Expresses reluctance to shower and undress in front of others, showing discomfort but complies nonetheless.
Closes her eyes and tries to shut out distressing surroundings, showing vulnerability and a need for self-soothing.
Does not interact with others in the showers despite their presence, remains isolated and inward-focused.
Tries to rationalize and calm herself by repeating 'It isn't real' despite disturbing and inexplicable phenomena.

Avoids eye contact with Parsons while being watched bandaged, suggesting feelings of guilt or embarrassment impairing her confidence.

Thanks Shelley after her confusing explanation, despite feeling foolish.

Leaves conversation quietly without confrontation when feeling confused or uncomfortable.

Is being sought urgently by colleagues and officials, indicating she might be trusted or relied upon.
